website_summaries.verdict: Best non-electric way to plant tulip, daffodil, lily and dahlia bulbs.
pros: Faster and easier than using a trowel
Simply insert into dirt, twist and remove
Product holds dirt while you plant bulb, and then releases dirt to cover the bulb
Many owners say that the metal has never bent
cons: If you have hard and rocky soil, you'll have to exert more energy

customer_reviews.title: Quick bulb planting
customer_reviews.text: This makes bulb planting much easier and neater than using a trowel. You just push down with a twist on the spot you want to plant your bulb. You pull out a tube of dirt that the planter holds onto for you. Drop your bulb in place, release the dirt back down by pressing with your thumb, step on it to pack it back down, and voila`, you're done and even your mulch on top had pretty much stayed in the right place.
customer_reviews.author: JGal

customer_reviews.title: Planting was a breeze.
customer_reviews.text: I planted 30 tulip bulbs in 24 minutes yesterday -including laying out the grid. It worked neatly and held the dirt well. Note that it only goes 4 inches in depth. My tulips called for six inches, so I had to press it a bit below the surface of the dirt. It wasn't a problem for me, but should be noted if you have bulbs that need deeper planting.
customer_reviews.author: accidental traverler x

customer_reviews.title: Sturdy
customer_reviews.text: Sturdy enough to take my hard use. I am a strong adult male. I put my weight into this thing and twisted it to get deep despite a few very small rocks. The device was not damaged. As for corrosion over time, we'll have to see.
customer_reviews.author: Linda J. Advena

customer_reviews.title: Sturdy tool but doesn't hold soil very well.. READ ON
customer_reviews.text: Honestly, this didn't work for me. I thought it was this super "plant your bulbs tool" but I ended up using a little hoe thing. It works OK for pushing in the soil and pushing in circles BUT the "grab the soil part" doesn't work. it just falls out anyway. This could be user error because it takes a strong hand to squeeze it as well. You can get the depth but the soil doesn't stay in the tool, for me at least. For the cheap price i'll save myself the aggravation of sending it back. The tool itself seems like its sturdy so I have no problems with it's quality. Hope this helps, Kim
customer_reviews.author: Cavimom

customer_reviews.title: Changed my garden life!!
customer_reviews.text: I have mobility issues but still love to garden. This summer, for the first time, I planted SPRING bulbs---had done fall bulbs last year-- and I used my new bulb planter....and OMG !!!....it changed my gardening life !!! So much faster and less strain on my body for several reasons. Why didn't I buy this years ago ??!! I also use it just to get holes started for other plantings.. This fall will see if you have a bigger one for my large bulbs.😁 Very happy with sturdiness and ease of soil release. Thank you Edward tools! Jennifer Z. Iowa City
customer_reviews.author: Jennifer Zaichenko

customer_reviews.title: Excellent tool. But I don't use it for planting ...
customer_reviews.text: Excellent tool. But I don't use it for planting bulbs I use it for Excavating items I find with my metal detector I needed something sturdy and this one feels very sturdy and should last a while. I pinpoint on the item with my detector and with the bulb planting tool I'm able to bring up the item.
customer_reviews.author: donald Norton

customer_reviews.title: HUGE but it works great
customer_reviews.text: At first impression, I was bummed because I thought it would be smaller. When I took it outside, I notice the depth measurements on the side of the bulb digger and I started to like it. Twist it into the ground to the depth you want, pop the bulb into the freshly dug hole, and then invert the bulb digger to put dirt on top of the bulb. Pack down the dirt or else the chipmunks will dig it up.
customer_reviews.author: J M

customer_reviews.title: Perfect for bulb planting!
customer_reviews.text: It worked great for all my planting this year. We just moved into a new house and so I have a lot of work to do on the landscape. This tool is the best when it comes to planting bulbs at the correct depth. I used it for planting seedlings as well. It's a good all around tool.
customer_reviews.author: ASong2sing2

customer_reviews.title: Quality Gardening Tool
customer_reviews.text: I was disappointed with the size- I thought it would be bigger, as I needed this tool to plant daffodil bulbs, which should be 6-9" in the dirt. This tool is for digging 4" deep holes. I likely misread something on the ad, so I'm not faulting the seller. I used it and it worked great! I had about 40 bulbs in the ground in less than a half hour. I like the weight and sturdiness of the tool. I'm sure I'll have it for many years to come and will be planting a lot more bulbs next year! Thanks for putting out a quality gardening tool!
customer_reviews.author: B. Payne

customer_reviews.title: Easy to dig holes in our clay-like soil
customer_reviews.text: This is a must have gardening tool. I’m a very reluctant gardener but with this tool, I was able to plant all my flower and vegetable plants in minutes. I love it.
customer_reviews.author: pv1940

customer_reviews.title: Very good product
customer_reviews.text: worked great! I like the easy release button on the handle. I planted about 40 bulbs today and had no issues with it. Seems well constructed and I think it will hold up well for years to come.
customer_reviews.author: Christine

customer_reviews.title: Great bulb planter
customer_reviews.text: I had just purchased a similar bulb planter from a well known store, but when I got home and tried to use it to plant bulbs it almost fell apart. I then went to amazon.com and purchased the Edward Tools Bulb Planter - Bend Free Tool for Planting Bulbs. It worked great for planting my bulbs. It was so sturdy and easy to use, I also used it to plant three small shrubs. Thank you for a great product!!
customer_reviews.author: T. Allen

customer_reviews.title: Great bulb planter, time saver
customer_reviews.text: I can attest to it being able to dig 88 holes in mountain soil without a hitch. My wife loved this thing, said it made getting those 88 bulbs into the ground much easier than if she were just using her small garden spade. Of course it isn't much use in big rocky soil, we have a few patches of that, but that is to be expected. Nothing much works in that soil save a pick ax. She is happy with this garden gizmo and would definitely buy it again when it wears out.

customer_reviews.title: Not the best product
customer_reviews.text: It bent after I used it a couple times. Worked ok, but I will not be using this again. Its half broken and keeps bending.
customer_reviews.author: Merideth Landry

customer_reviews.title: Easy bulb planting
customer_reviews.text: I just planted 80 tulip bulbs and this worked like a dream. It made planting much easier than last year when I used a spade. It takes out a perfect plug of soil , pop in the bulb and put the plug of soil right back in. It's not rickety or loose feeling at all and held up well despite hitting numerous rocks. I'm glad I bought this and I'll probably plant more bulbs next year as it made it more fun and less tedious.
customer_reviews.author: samantha

customer_reviews.title: Good tool, but could be sturdier
customer_reviews.text: Works well enough. Not as sturdy as I had hoped for. I researched and bought this because it claims to be bend free and strong. It is well made, but certainly not heavy duty. But study enough for most jobs.
customer_reviews.author: Kirk Hodges

customer_reviews.title: may work fine under ideal conditions
customer_reviews.text: first i admit i wasn't planting bulbs and not in loose well drained soil. I wanted to dig a small hole to plant seedlings. the soil was clay and moist. the first few holes were just right, but the moist clay clung to the planter and the 'automatic soil release' didn't. toward the end of my ordeal the soil got heavier and the planter all but collapsed to the side. as i said it may work fine under ideal conditions.
customer_reviews.author: CharlieB

customer_reviews.title: For use in very soft soil or top soil only!
customer_reviews.text: I'm in Ohio. Our dirt is just normal I'd say, not like clay but not overly soft. This bent and broke on the second hole! Looked pretty much like the picture someone else posted with their bent one. This would work excellent in topsoil or sandy soil, any soft ground but it sure did not work here for me! I would not recommend this for anyone not planting in a very soft soil.
customer_reviews.author: Amy

customer_reviews.title: This makes planting so much easier.
customer_reviews.text: My hands are not as strong as they used to be, and I also have a hard time kneeling to do my gardening. A friend recommended this to help with planting. I was able to plant a flat of flowers quickly and easily using this tool to dig the holes. I also used it to plant my potted plants. My hands, knees and back we're spared the usual strain from planting. I'm grateful that my friend told me about this.
customer_reviews.author: T. Todd

customer_reviews.title: (Fairly) easy way to make bulb holes
customer_reviews.text: I noted "fairly" easy because I gave this tool a real workout. I made holes for bulbs on the side of a steep hill, in very rocky and clay soil. That's probably the worst to dig (except Tennessee clay!!) and the tool did the job. I used a twisting motion, and the dirt to be removed stayed in the tool until I clicked the handle to release it. Great tool!
customer_reviews.author: tomtees

customer_reviews.title: Versitile uses
customer_reviews.text: This is marketed for planting bulbs, but can be used for excavating holes into which many nursery plants can be placed. For most soil types, the soil is removed by the planter in one lump that can be dumped to the side by squeezing the handle. Looser, drier sandier soils will be less coherent, so insert the planter, press down on the soil at the top of the barrel to compact it and lift the planter out. Don't use it to dig out rocks and it will perform well and last indefinitely.
customer_reviews.author: RMS

customer_reviews.title: not very durable; comes apart
customer_reviews.text: While this tool is adequate for digging decent holes (doesn't bring up or catch all the dirt), it came apart and the spring popped out within my frist four uses. I put it back together again as good as possible, but it is not very high quality. I would actually consider returning it, but don't know that it's worth the trouble (cost to me or Amazon). It's not horrible, but not very good either . . . and does the job of digging holes for perennial bulbs semi-well.
customer_reviews.author: Todd R. Theurer

customer_reviews.title: ... around to planting bulbs and found this close to useless. It has been raining and the soil is ...
customer_reviews.text: I finally got around to planting bulbs and found this close to useless. It has been raining and the soil is wet and would stay in the planter which I had to force out. The spring release mechanism didn't help. After planting about 10 bulbs the planter bent and eventually became useless. It bent because of the joint to open and "release" dirt. Next time I will buy a solid planter.
customer_reviews.author: Michael K

customer_reviews.title: Great for clay soil
customer_reviews.text: My soil is hard and clay-like, and so I was dreading planting 150 bulbs last month. But - easy peasy. I twisted back and forth on it while pushing down slightly, and the tool went right down into the soil. When it was the correct depth, I pulled it out and a plug of soil came out with it (inside it). Still hard work (I had a blister on my palm after several hours) but WAY easier than any other method.
customer_reviews.author: Eva Mitnick

customer_reviews.title: So easy to use

I had them all planted in less than half an hour and still had energy left to pull weeds and do all the other stuff that always presents itself in any garden. Thank you a million times for this tool!
customer_reviews.author: Ann P. Wilson

customer_reviews.title: Pleasantly surprised

Simply push down and twist, up comes the dirt leaving a perfect hole of whatever depth you desire. Pop the bulb in and release the dirt into the hole, tamp down, and bingo. Worked very well in the wet soil I had. Can't say how it might work in sandy, dry soil.

customer_reviews.title: Works well

customer_reviews.title: A MUST HAVE TOOL!

customer_reviews.title: GREAT product, low price

customer_reviews.title: Great little tool!  More than just for bulbs.

product_meta.description: Bulb Planter is the ideal bulb planting tool for planting tulips, daffodils and other flower bulbs. This high end bulb planter features a lifetime warranty, reinforced steel, adjustable handle hinge, soil release and depth marker. For hard to penetrate soils this bulb planter features reinforced chrome plated steel that keeps the tool from bending and allows for quicker planting. The adjustable soil release feature is done by pushing the ergonomic handle together and soil falls into the hole where the bulb is planted. Edward Tools bulb planter makes bulb planter more precise with a depth marker from 1 to 4 inches.
